title: 1¬† The Sun‚Äôs Lifespan and Energy
text:
1.2 The Sun: Our Star
The Sun is a middle-aged star about 4.6 billion years old. It will continue to shine for another 5 billion years before exhausting its hydrogen fuel.

1.2.1 Nuclear Fusion
The Sun produces energy through nuclear fusion - combining hydrogen atoms into helium in its core.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Distance from center (in solar radii)
radius = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)

# Temperature profile (simplified model)
temp = 15.7 * np.exp(-4.5 * radius) + 0.006  # millions of Kelvin

# Density profile (simplified model)
density = 160 * np.exp(-8 * radius)  # g/cm¬≥

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12, 5))

# Temperature plot
ax1.plot(radius, temp, 'r-', linewidth=2)
ax1.fill_between(radius, temp, alpha=0.3, color='red')
ax1.set_xlabel('Distance from Center (Solar Radii)')
ax1.set_ylabel('Temperature (millions K)')
ax1.set_title('Temperature Profile of the Sun')
ax1.axvspan(0, 0.25, alpha=0.2, color='yellow', label='Core')
ax1.axvspan(0.25, 0.7, alpha=0.2, color='orange', label='Radiative Zone')
ax1.axvspan(0.7, 1.0, alpha=0.2, color='red', label='Convective Zone')
ax1.legend()
ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# Density plot
ax2.plot(radius, density, 'b-', linewidth=2)
ax2.fill_between(radius, density, alpha=0.3, color='blue')
ax2.set_xlabel('Distance from Center (Solar Radii)')
ax2.set_ylabel('Density (g/cm¬≥)')
ax2.set_title('Density Profile of the Sun')
ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()








Figure¬†1.1: Temperature and density profile of the Sun

title: 14¬† Moon Phases, Eclipses, and Tides
text:
14.2 Moon Phases
The Moon‚Äôs appearance changes throughout its 29.5-day cycle as we see different portions of its illuminated half.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.patches as mpatches
import numpy as np

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 4, figsize=(14, 7))
axes = axes.flatten()

phases = [
    ('New Moon', 0),
    ('Waxing Crescent', 0.125),
    ('First Quarter', 0.25),
    ('Waxing Gibbous', 0.375),
    ('Full Moon', 0.5),
    ('Waning Gibbous', 0.625),
    ('Third Quarter', 0.75),
    ('Waning Crescent', 0.875)
]

for ax, (name, phase) in zip(axes, phases):
    ax.set_xlim(-1.5, 1.5)
    ax.set_ylim(-1.5, 1.5)
    ax.set_aspect('equal')
    ax.axis('off')
    
    # Draw moon outline
    circle = plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, fill=False, color='gray', linewidth=2)
    ax.add_patch(circle)
    
    # Draw illuminated portion
    theta = np.linspace(-np.pi/2, np.pi/2, 100)
    
    if phase == 0:  # New Moon
        ax.add_patch(plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, color='#1a1a2e'))
    elif phase == 0.5:  # Full Moon
        ax.add_patch(plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, color='#f5f5dc'))
    elif phase < 0.5:  # Waxing
        ax.add_patch(plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, color='#1a1a2e'))
        illumination = (phase * 4 - 1) if phase > 0.25 else -(1 - phase * 4)
        x_edge = illumination * np.cos(theta)
        x_right = np.cos(theta)
        y = np.sin(theta)
        ax.fill(np.concatenate([x_right, x_edge[::-1]]), 
                np.concatenate([y, y[::-1]]), color='#f5f5dc')
    else:  # Waning
        ax.add_patch(plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, color='#f5f5dc'))
        illumination = ((phase - 0.5) * 4 - 1) if phase > 0.75 else -(1 - (phase - 0.5) * 4)
        x_edge = illumination * np.cos(theta)
        x_right = np.cos(theta)
        y = np.sin(theta)
        ax.fill(np.concatenate([x_right, x_edge[::-1]]), 
                np.concatenate([y, y[::-1]]), color='#1a1a2e')
    
    ax.set_title(name, fontsize=11, fontweight='bold')

plt.suptitle('Phases of the Moon', fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', y=1.02)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()








Figure¬†14.1: The eight major phases of the Moon

title: 15¬† Earth System Feedbacks
text:
15.2 What Are Feedback Loops?
A feedback loop occurs when a change in one part of a system causes changes that either amplify (positive feedback) or reduce (negative feedback) the original change.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.patches as mpatches

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(14, 6))

# Positive Feedback
ax1.set_xlim(0, 10)
ax1.set_ylim(0, 10)
ax1.axis('off')
ax1.set_title('POSITIVE FEEDBACK\n(Amplifying)', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', color='red')

# Boxes
boxes1 = [
    (5, 8, 'Temperature\nIncreases', '#ffcccc'),
    (8, 5, 'Ice/Snow\nMelts', '#ccccff'),
    (5, 2, 'Less Sunlight\nReflected', '#ffffcc'),
    (2, 5, 'More Heat\nAbsorbed', '#ffcccc')
]

for x, y, text, color in boxes1:
    ax1.add_patch(mpatches.FancyBboxPatch((x-1.2, y-0.8), 2.4, 1.6, 
                  boxstyle="round,pad=0.1", facecolor=color, edgecolor='red', linewidth=2))
    ax1.text(x, y, text, ha='center', va='center', fontsize=9)

# Arrows (circular)
arrow_style = dict(arrowstyle='->', color='red', lw=2)
ax1.annotate('', xy=(7.5, 6.5), xytext=(6, 7.5), arrowprops=arrow_style)
ax1.annotate('', xy=(6.5, 2.5), xytext=(7.5, 4), arrowprops=arrow_style)
ax1.annotate('', xy=(2.5, 4), xytext=(4, 2.5), arrowprops=arrow_style)
ax1.annotate('', xy=(4, 7.5), xytext=(2.5, 6), arrowprops=arrow_style)

ax1.text(5, 5, 'üîÑ\nRUNAWAY\nEFFECT', ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', color='red')

# Negative Feedback
ax2.set_xlim(0, 10)
ax2.set_ylim(0, 10)
ax2.axis('off')
ax2.set_title('NEGATIVE FEEDBACK\n(Stabilizing)', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', color='green')

boxes2 = [
    (5, 8, 'Temperature\nIncreases', '#ffcccc'),
    (8, 5, 'More\nEvaporation', '#ccccff'),
    (5, 2, 'More Clouds\nForm', '#e0e0e0'),
    (2, 5, 'More Sunlight\nReflected', '#ccffcc')
]

for x, y, text, color in boxes2:
    ax2.add_patch(mpatches.FancyBboxPatch((x-1.2, y-0.8), 2.4, 1.6, 
                  boxstyle="round,pad=0.1", facecolor=color, edgecolor='green', linewidth=2))
    ax2.text(x, y, text, ha='center', va='center', fontsize=9)

# Arrows
arrow_style2 = dict(arrowstyle='->', color='green', lw=2)
ax2.annotate('', xy=(7.5, 6.5), xytext=(6, 7.5), arrowprops=arrow_style2)
ax2.annotate('', xy=(6.5, 2.5), xytext=(7.5, 4), arrowprops=arrow_style2)
ax2.annotate('', xy=(2.5, 4), xytext=(4, 2.5), arrowprops=arrow_style2)
ax2.annotate('', xy=(4, 7.5), xytext=(2.5, 6), arrowprops=arrow_style2)

15¬† Earth System Feedbacks
text:
15.5 Water Vapor Feedback
Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas and creates a powerful positive feedback.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(14, 5))

# Clausius-Clapeyron relationship
temps = np.linspace(-20, 40, 100)
saturation_vapor = 6.11 * np.exp(17.27 * temps / (temps + 237.3))  # hPa

ax1.plot(temps, saturation_vapor, 'b-', linewidth=3)
ax1.fill_between(temps, saturation_vapor, alpha=0.3)
ax1.set_xlabel('Temperature (¬∞C)', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_ylabel('Saturation Vapor Pressure (hPa)', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_title('Clausius-Clapeyron Relationship', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# Annotate
ax1.annotate('~7% more water vapor\nper 1¬∞C warming', xy=(20, 23), xytext=(5, 40),
             arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='red'),
             fontsize=10, color='red')

# Feedback loop diagram
ax2.set_xlim(0, 10)
ax2.set_ylim(0, 10)
ax2.axis('off')
ax2.set_title('Water Vapor Positive Feedback', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')

steps = [
    (5, 9, '1. CO‚ÇÇ increases', '#ffcccc'),
    (8.5, 7, '2. Temperature rises', '#ffddcc'),
    (8.5, 4, '3. More evaporation', '#cce5ff'),
    (5, 2, '4. More water vapor\n(greenhouse gas)', '#ccffcc'),
    (1.5, 4, '5. Enhanced\ngreenhouse effect', '#ffffcc'),
    (1.5, 7, '6. More warming', '#ffcccc')
]

for x, y, text, color in steps:
    ax2.add_patch(mpatches.FancyBboxPatch((x-1.3, y-0.7), 2.6, 1.4, 
                  boxstyle="round,pad=0.1", facecolor=color, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1))
    ax2.text(x, y, text, ha='center', va='center', fontsize=8)

# Arrows
for i in range(5):
    ax2.annotate('', xy=(steps[(i+1)%6][0], steps[(i+1)%6][1]), 
                 xytext=(steps[i][0], steps[i][1]),
                 arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='red', lw=1.5,
                                connectionstyle='arc3,rad=0.2'))

ax2.text(5, 5.5, 'üîÑ AMPLIFYING\nLOOP', ha='center', va='center', 
         fontsize=11, fontweight='bold', color='red')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()








Figure¬†15.3: Water vapor feedback mechanism











Key Concept



Water vapor feedback approximately doubles the warming effect of CO‚ÇÇ alone. For every 1¬∞C of warming from CO‚ÇÇ, water vapor adds another ~1¬∞C of warming.

Earth receives energy from the Sun and radiates energy back to space. The balance determines our planet‚Äôs temperature.

17.3 3.1 Investigative Phenomenon: Patterns in Earth‚Äôs Past

17.3.1 The Mystery of Glacial Cycles
Earth‚Äôs climate has not been stable throughout human history. Our planet has experienced dramatic swings between ice ages (glacial periods) and warmer periods (interglacial periods). Understanding what caused these past climate changes is essential for determining whether today‚Äôs warming is natural or caused by human activities.

title: 17¬† Chapter 3: Earth-Sun Dynamics
text:
17.4 3.2 Milankovitch Cycles: Earth‚Äôs Orbital Variations

17.4.1 Introduction to Orbital Factors
In the 1920s, Serbian scientist Milutin Milankoviƒá proposed that long-term changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit and axial tilt could explain the glacial-interglacial cycles[1]. These variations, now called Milankovitch cycles, affect how much solar radiation reaches different parts of Earth at different times of year.
There are three main orbital factors that change over time:


17.4.2 3.2.1 Eccentricity: The Shape of Earth‚Äôs Orbit
What is it?
Eccentricity describes how circular or elliptical (oval-shaped) Earth‚Äôs orbit is. When eccentricity is low, Earth‚Äôs orbit is nearly circular. When eccentricity is high, the orbit is more elliptical, meaning Earth gets closer to and farther from the Sun during its yearly revolution.
Interactive Visualization: Manipulate Earth‚Äôs orbital eccentricity and observe how it changes Earth‚Äôs distance from the Sun: Earth‚Äôs Orbit Simulator - University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Cycle length: Approximately 100,000 years (with variations around 95,000-125,000 years)
How does it affect climate?
Current status: Earth‚Äôs orbit is currently nearly circular (low eccentricity) and becoming more circular over the next 50,000 years.


17.4.3 3.2.2 Obliquity: Earth‚Äôs Axial Tilt
What is it?
Obliquity is the angle between Earth‚Äôs rotational axis and a line perpendicular to its orbital plane. You learned in Chapter 2 that this tilt is what causes seasons. However, the amount of tilt changes over time.
\begin{figure}
\end{figure>
Interactive Demo: Adjust Earth‚Äôs axial tilt and observe how it affects seasonal sunlight distribution: Seasons Interactive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Cycle length: Approximately 41,000 years
How does it affect climate?
Current status: Earth‚Äôs tilt is currently 23.4¬∞ and decreasing (moving toward less extreme seasons).


17.4.4 3.2.3 Precession: The Direction of Earth‚Äôs Tilt
What is it?
Precession refers to the slow ‚Äúwobble‚Äù of Earth‚Äôs axis, similar to how a spinning top wobbles. This changes which direction Earth‚Äôs North Pole points in space. Currently, Earth‚Äôs axis points toward Polaris (the North Star), but 13,000 years ago it pointed toward the star Vega.
Cycle length: Approximately 26,000 years (combined with orbital precession creates a 21,000-year cycle)
How does it affect climate?
Precession determines the timing of when Earth is closest to and farthest from the Sun relative to the seasons:
Current status: Northern Hemisphere is currently tilted away from the Sun during perihelion (closest approach), resulting in relatively cool summers.


17.4.5 Combining the Three Factors
The three Milankovitch cycles operate simultaneously and combine to influence climate:
Key Concept: High-latitude summer insolation is the critical factor. Cool summers allow snow and ice to persist year-round, enabling ice sheets to grow. Warm summers cause melting that prevents or reverses ice sheet growth.

17.6.5 Synthesis: The Milankovitch Theory
After analyzing these three major climate transitions, you should be able to see a pattern:
Key Insight: Ice sheets grow when high-latitude summers are cool (snow doesn‚Äôt melt), and they shrink when high-latitude summers are warm (snow and ice melt). Milankovitch cycles change the intensity of high-latitude summers, thereby controlling ice sheet growth and retreat.

title: 17¬† Chapter 3: Earth-Sun Dynamics
section: 17.7 3.5 Computational Model: Testing the Full Milankovitch Theory
text:
17.7 3.5 Computational Model: Testing the Full Milankovitch Theory

17.7.1 Using the Vostok Ice Core Interactive
While your physical models and analysis of specific transitions provide strong evidence for the Milankovitch theory, you can test this theory more rigorously using a computational model that shows all 400,000 years of data.
Access the interactive model: The Vostok Core and Milankovitch Cycles Interactive
The Vostok ice core was drilled in Antarctica by Russian and American scientists, reaching a depth of 3,623 meters. Air bubbles trapped in the ice preserve ancient atmospheric gases, allowing scientists to reconstruct temperature changes over 400,000 years.
How to Use the Interactive:


17.7.2 Familiarization Questions
Before analyzing the data, explore the model to understand its features:


17.7.3 Testing Individual Factors
Now you‚Äôll test whether each orbital factor correlates with (matches) the temperature pattern.

Precession Test:
Question: Does precession alone closely match the temperature pattern? Support your answer with evidence.
Obliquity (Tilt) Test:

title: 17¬† Chapter 3: Earth-Sun Dynamics
section: 17.8 3.6 Solar Cycles: Does the Sun‚Äôs Output Change?
text:
17.8 3.6 Solar Cycles: Does the Sun‚Äôs Output Change?

17.8.1 A New Question
The Milankovitch theory explains climate changes based on how Earth‚Äôs position affects the distribution of solar radiation across the planet. But what if the Sun itself changes‚Äîwhat if it produces more or less energy over time? Could variations in the Sun‚Äôs energy output also contribute to climate change?


17.8.2 Understanding Solar Cycles
The Sun is not a perfectly constant star. Its energy output varies slightly over time, driven by changes in solar magnetic activity. The most visible evidence of this is sunspots‚Äîdark regions on the Sun‚Äôs surface that indicate strong magnetic activity.
Interactive Data Explorer: Explore current and historical sunspot activity with real NASA data: NOAA Solar Cycle Progression
Real-Time Solar Activity: View the Sun right now with live satellite imagery: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory
Key observations:


17.8.3 Analysis Activity: Sunspots and Temperature
Examine the graph showing sunspot activity and global temperature over the past 10,000 years.
Questions:


17.8.4 The Solar Cycle Timescale
Examine the detailed graph of solar cycles over recent centuries:
Analysis Questions:


17.8.5 Key Findings About Solar Cycles
Based on your analysis:
Conclusion: While the Sun‚Äôs output does vary over time, these variations operate on a much shorter timescale than the major climate changes of the past 400,000 years. Milankovitch cycles, not solar cycles, provide the best explanation for glacial-interglacial cycling.

17.9 3.7 Performance Task: Orbital Factors and Today‚Äôs Climate

17.9.1 The Critical Question
You‚Äôve established that Milankovitch cycles caused major climate changes in the past. Now you must address the most important question for understanding today‚Äôs climate:
Are orbital factors responsible for current global warming?


17.9.2 Current Orbital Configuration

The fact that Earth is actually experiencing ________________ [cooling/warming] at a rate of _______ ¬∞C per century indicates that __________________________________________________.‚Äù

title: 17¬† Chapter 3: Earth-Sun Dynamics
text:
17.10 3.8 Chapter Summary

17.10.1 Key Concepts



17.10.2 Three-Dimensional Learning
Science and Engineering Practices:
Crosscutting Concepts:
Disciplinary Core Ideas:


17.10.3 Driving Question Answered
What factors have contributed to climate change in the past and are they contributing to climate change now?
Milankovitch cycles (changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit and axial tilt) have been the primary driver of major climate changes over the past several hundred thousand years, causing glacial-interglacial cycles through changes in high-latitude summer insolation. However, current orbital parameters predict gradual cooling, not the rapid warming observed over the past 200 years. This discrepancy indicates that orbital factors are NOT responsible for current climate change‚Äîother factors must be at play. In the next chapter, you‚Äôll investigate what those factors might be.


17.10.4 Looking Ahead
You‚Äôve ruled out natural orbital variations as the cause of recent warming. You‚Äôve also seen that solar output variations operate on too short a timescale. This leads to a critical question for the next chapter:
If natural factors can‚Äôt explain current warming, what can?
In Chapter 4, you‚Äôll investigate the role of greenhouse gases, feedback mechanisms, and human activities in driving rapid climate change.

Phenomenon
Global average temperatures have risen approximately 1.1¬∞C since the pre-industrial era, with accelerating impacts on ice sheets, sea levels, and extreme weather. What‚Äôs driving these changes?


Code
import plotly.express as px
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Simulated global temperature data
np.random.seed(42)
years = list(range(1880, 2026))
baseline_trend = [(y - 1880) * 0.007 for y in years]
acceleration = [0.00005 * (y - 1950)**2 if y > 1950 else 0 for y in years]
noise = np.random.normal(0, 0.1, len(years))
temps = [b + a + n - 0.2 for b, a, n in zip(baseline_trend, acceleration, noise)]

df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Year': years,
    'Temperature Anomaly (¬∞C)': temps
})

fig = px.bar(df, x='Year', y='Temperature Anomaly (¬∞C)',
             color='Temperature Anomaly (¬∞C)',
             color_continuous_scale=['blue', 'white', 'red'],
             range_color=[-0.5, 1.5],
             title='Global Temperature Anomaly (1880-2025)')
fig.add_hline(y=0, line_dash='dash', line_color='black')
fig.update_layout(height=450)
fig

title: 16¬† Unit 4: Earth-Sun Dynamics 5E
text:
20.1 üåç The Mechanism
Key Insight: It‚Äôs not total yearly radiation that matters most‚Äîit‚Äôs summer radiation at high northern latitudes (around 65¬∞N).

20.1.1 Why 65¬∞N Matters:

Most of Earth‚Äôs land mass is in the Northern Hemisphere
Ice sheets grow when summer is NOT warm enough to melt winter snow
When summer radiation at 65¬∞N is LOW, ice sheets expand
When summer radiation at 65¬∞N is HIGH, ice sheets retreat



20.1.2 The Feedback Loop:
Low summer radiation ‚Üí Snow persists ‚Üí Ice sheets grow ‚Üí 
Higher albedo ‚Üí More cooling ‚Üí More ice growth

title: 16¬† Unit 4: Earth-Sun Dynamics 5E
text:
20.2 Comparing Radiation and Temperature


Code
combinedData = iceCoreTempData.map((d, i) => ({

  width: 750,

    Plot.text([{x: 350, y: 2}], {x: "x", y: "y", text: d => "Temperature", fill: "#e74c3c", fontSize: 12})
  ]
})

















20.2.1 üí° Key Ideas: Earth-Sun Dynamics

Temperatures on Earth have fluctuated greatly during human history, marked by glacial and interglacial periods
A pattern exists in the frequency of these fluctuations (~100,000 years)
The pattern is explained by cyclical changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit shape and tilt
These changes cause ice sheets to expand and retreat
Current orbital parameters suggest Earth should be cooling, yet global temperatures are increasing

text:
22.1 üìä Putting It Together
Based on current orbital parameters:









Parameter
Current Value

Climate Effect




Eccentricity
0.017
Decreasing

23.44¬∞

title: 16¬† Unit 4: Earth-Sun Dynamics 5E
text:
22.2 üìù Earth-Sun Dynamics Quiz
Question 1: What is the approximate period of the eccentricity cycle? - A) 23,000 years - B) 41,000 years - C) 100,000 years - D) 1 million years
Question 2: Why is summer radiation at 65¬∞N latitude so important for ice ages? - A) It‚Äôs where most people live - B) It‚Äôs where most land mass is located, and ice sheets need cool summers to persist - C) The Sun is closest to Earth at this latitude - D) Ocean currents are strongest here
Question 3: Earth‚Äôs current axial tilt is approximately: - A) 22.1¬∞ - B) 23.5¬∞ - C) 24.5¬∞ - D) 45¬∞
Question 4: According to Milankovitch cycles, what should Earth‚Äôs climate be doing right now? - A) Warming rapidly - B) Staying constant - C) Cooling gradually - D) Experiencing an ice age
Question 5: What causes the ~100,000 year glacial-interglacial cycle? - A) Changes in the Sun‚Äôs energy output - B) Volcanic activity - C) Changes in Earth‚Äôs orbital eccentricity - D) Human activity
Question 6: The precession cycle affects climate by: - A) Changing total solar radiation received - B) Changing which season occurs at perihelion vs aphelion - C) Changing Earth‚Äôs distance from the Sun - D) Changing the Sun‚Äôs output
Question 7: If Earth‚Äôs axial tilt increased to 24.5¬∞, seasons would become: - A) Less extreme - B) More extreme - C) Unchanged - D) Reversed
Question 8: What is the significance of global warming occurring despite Milankovitch cycles predicting cooling? - A) Milankovitch cycles are wrong - B) Another factor must be causing the warming - C) The Sun‚Äôs output has increased dramatically - D) Earth‚Äôs orbit has changed unexpectedly
Answers: 1-C, 2-B, 3-B, 4-C, 5-C, 6-B, 7-B, 8-B

21.1 What is Albedo?
Albedo is the measure of how much light a surface reflects. It ranges from 0 (absorbs all light) to 1 (reflects all light).

title: 17¬† Unit 4: Climate Feedbacks 5E
text:
22.1 üîÑ Understanding Climate Feedbacks
A feedback loop occurs when the output of a system affects its input, creating a cycle.

22.1.1 Positive Feedback (Amplifying)
Makes changes BIGGER - the system amplifies itself


22.1.2 Negative Feedback (Stabilizing)
Makes changes SMALLER - the system stabilizes itself

title: 17¬† Unit 4: Climate Feedbacks 5E
17¬† Unit 4: Climate Feedbacks 5E
text:
22.3 üåç Why the Arctic Warms 4x Faster
The Ice-Albedo Feedback explains Arctic amplification:

Arctic has lots of ice (high albedo ~60%)
Global warming melts some ice
Dark ocean exposed (low albedo ~6%)
Ocean absorbs 10x more energy than ice did
Local temperature rises dramatically
More ice melts ‚Üí cycle continues

This is why the Arctic is the ‚Äúcanary in the coal mine‚Äù for climate change!

23.2.1 üí° Key Ideas: Climate Feedbacks

The greenhouse effect explains why increasing CO‚ÇÇ leads to global warming
Albedo is the tendency of a surface to reflect or absorb radiation
Ice has high albedo (~60%) compared to seawater (~6%)
As ice melts, more radiation is absorbed, causing more warming ‚Üí positive feedback
Arctic amplification (4x faster warming) is explained by ice-albedo feedback
Multiple feedback loops (ice-albedo, water vapor, permafrost) amplify climate change
Human activities have dramatically increased CO‚ÇÇ levels beyond natural ranges

title: 17¬† Unit 4: Climate Feedbacks 5E
text:
24.1 üìä Performance Task Check-In
Using what you‚Äôve learned, you can now explain:

Why scientists are confident humans are causing climate change:

CO‚ÇÇ levels are far beyond natural range (420 ppm vs.¬†max 280 ppm)
The timing matches industrialization
Natural factors (Milankovitch cycles, solar output) can‚Äôt explain current warming

Why the Arctic is warming so fast:

Ice-albedo feedback amplifies warming
As ice melts, dark ocean absorbs more energy
This creates a self-reinforcing cycle

How feedbacks make climate change worse:

Ice-albedo: melting ice ‚Üí more absorption ‚Üí more melting
Water vapor: warming ‚Üí more evaporation ‚Üí more greenhouse effect
Permafrost: warming ‚Üí methane release ‚Üí more warming

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
text:
21.1 What is AMOC?
The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is a massive system of ocean currents that acts like a global conveyor belt, moving warm water from the tropics to the North Atlantic and cold water back southward at depth.

  Ocean Conveyor Belt Diagram
  
  The global thermohaline circulation (ocean conveyor belt)
crumbs: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
crumbs: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
text:
21.3 üåä How AMOC Works
The key driver of AMOC is DENSITY:

Warm, salty water flows north from the tropics
In the North Atlantic, water cools and becomes denser
High salinity makes the water even denser
Dense water sinks to the deep ocean
Deep water flows southward along the ocean floor
This creates a continuous circulation pattern

What happens when ice melts: - Melting ice sheets add freshwater to the North Atlantic - Freshwater is less dense than saltwater - Less dense water doesn‚Äôt sink as well - AMOC slows down or stops
crumbs: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
text:
21.4 üî¨ Lab Activity: Density-Driven Currents

21.4.1 Materials:

Clear rectangular container (aquarium or large baking dish)
Ice cubes (some colored with blue food dye)
Salt
Warm water (colored with red food dye)
Room temperature water
Thermometer



21.4.2 Procedure:
Part 1: Setting Up the ‚ÄúOcean‚Äù 1. Fill the container with room temperature water 2. Place blue ice cubes at one end (representing the Arctic) 3. Carefully add warm red water at the other end (representing the tropics) 4. Observe the movement of water
Part 2: Testing Salinity Effects 1. Reset the container with fresh water 2. Add salt to the warm water (make it as salty as seawater: ~35g per liter) 3. Add blue ice cubes at the cold end 4. Observe how salinity affects the circulation
Part 3: Simulating Ice Sheet Melt 1. While circulation is established, add plain (fresh) ice water at the ‚ÄúArctic‚Äù end 2. Observe what happens to the circulation pattern 3. Record your observations


21.4.3 Data Table:

Pattern Observed

21.4.4 Analysis Questions:

How does this relate to what might happen in the real Atlantic Ocean?

crumbs: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
section: 22.2 üìú Case Study: The Younger Dryas (12,900 - 11,700 years ago)
text:
22.2 üìú Case Study: The Younger Dryas (12,900 - 11,700 years ago)
The Scenario: - Earth was warming after the Last Glacial Maximum - Massive ice sheets over North America were melting - Lake Agassiz (larger than all Great Lakes combined) formed from meltwater
The Trigger: - Around 12,900 years ago, Lake Agassiz catastrophically drained - Enormous amounts of freshwater flooded into the North Atlantic - This freshwater was less dense than seawater
The Result: - AMOC slowed dramatically or stopped - Heat transfer to Northern Europe ceased - Temperatures in Greenland dropped ~10¬∞C in just decades - The Northern Hemisphere plunged back into ice age conditions - The cold period lasted ~1,200 years
crumbs: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E

title: 18¬† Unit 4: The Past and the Future 5E
text:
23.1 üîÑ The Feedback Mechanism
Step 1: Ice sheets melt ‚Üí freshwater enters North Atlantic
Step 2: Freshwater reduces salinity ‚Üí water less dense
Step 3: Water doesn‚Äôt sink as efficiently ‚Üí AMOC weakens
Step 4: Less heat transported northward ‚Üí Northern Hemisphere cools
Step 5: BUT‚Ä¶ Southern Hemisphere warms (heat accumulates at equator)
Step 6: Warmer Southern Ocean releases more CO‚ÇÇ ‚Üí amplifies global effects

text:
24.4 Climate Impacts Already Happening

24.4.1 üåç Current Climate Change Impacts

  
    üåä Sea Level Rise
    Current: ~3.7 mm/year (accelerating)
    Total since 1900: ~20 cm
    Impact: Coastal erosion, flooding, saltwater intrusion
  
  
    üî• Extreme Heat
    Trend: Heat waves 5x more likely
    Record: 2023 hottest year on record
    Impact: Heat deaths, crop failures, wildfires
  
  
    üåÄ Extreme Weather
    Trend: More intense hurricanes
    Rainfall: Heavier precipitation events
    Impact: Flooding, infrastructure damage
  
  
    üßä Ice Loss
    Arctic: -13% per decade
    Glaciers: Retreating worldwide
    Impact: Sea level rise, ecosystem loss
  
  
    üåæ Food Security
    Crops: Yields declining in some regions
    Fisheries: Species shifting poleward
    Impact: Food shortages, price increases
  
  
    üíß Water Resources
    Drought: More frequent and severe
    Snowpack: Declining in mountains
    Impact: Water shortages, conflicts

section: 25.2 üìù The Past and the Future Quiz
text:
25.2 üìù The Past and the Future Quiz
Question 1: What is AMOC? - A) A type of greenhouse gas - B) The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation - a major ocean current system - C) A glacier in Antarctica - D) A climate modeling computer
Question 2: What drives the sinking of water in the North Atlantic that powers AMOC? - A) Wind patterns - B) The Moon‚Äôs gravity - C) Cold, salty water being denser than warm, fresh water - D) Volcanic activity
Question 3: What triggered the Younger Dryas cooling event? - A) A volcanic eruption - B) A meteor impact - C) Massive freshwater release from melting ice sheets into the North Atlantic - D) Changes in the Sun‚Äôs output
Question 4: How long did the Younger Dryas last? - A) About 100 years - B) About 1,200 years - C) About 10,000 years - D) About 1 million years
Question 5: How did the Younger Dryas affect human populations? - A) It had no effect on humans - B) It helped humans develop agriculture faster - C) It delayed the agricultural revolution and caused population decline - D) It caused humans to migrate to Antarctica
Question 6: Current observations show that AMOC is: - A) Strengthening rapidly - B) Staying constant - C) Showing signs of weakening - D) Completely stopped
Question 7: Which ice sheet is losing mass fastest? - A) Greenland - B) Antarctica - C) They‚Äôre losing mass at equal rates - D) Neither is losing mass
Question 8: Approximately how many people globally could be displaced by 1 meter of sea level rise? - A) About 1 million - B) About 10 million - C) About 100 million or more - D) About 1,000 people
Question 9: Why is understanding past climate change important for preparing for future climate change? - A) It‚Äôs not important - the past is different from the future - B) Past events show how quickly climate can change and how populations can be affected - C) Past climates were always stable - D) We can‚Äôt learn anything from ice cores
Question 10: If AMOC were to significantly weaken or collapse today, what would likely happen to Europe? - A) It would get much warmer - B) It would experience significant cooling despite global warming - C) Nothing would change - D) It would experience more earthquakes
Answers: 1-B, 2-C, 3-C, 4-B, 5-C, 6-C, 7-A, 8-C, 9-B, 10-B

text:
21.2 Why Scientists Are Certain: The Complete Picture

21.2.1 The Scientific Consensus Explained
Multiple independent lines of evidence ALL point to the same conclusion:








Evidence Type
What It Shows
Natural Explanation?




Ice cores (CO‚ÇÇ)
CO‚ÇÇ at 800,000-year high
‚ùå No natural source


Carbon isotopes
Fossil fuel fingerprint
‚ùå Proves human origin


Warming pattern
Matches greenhouse effect
‚ùå Rules out solar


Timing
Matches industrialization
‚ùå Rules out natural cycles


Rate of change
100x faster than natural
‚ùå Rules out all natural causes


Climate models
Predictions match observations
‚úÖ Only works with human emissions



This is why 99.9% of climate scientists agree: The evidence is overwhelming and consistent across dozens of independent data sources and methods. There is no alternative explanation that fits all the evidence.

text:
25.2 üìù Unit Closing Assessment

25.2.1 Part A: Multiple Choice
Question 1: What is the main reason scientists are confident that current warming is NOT caused by changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit (Milankovitch cycles)? - A) Earth‚Äôs orbit hasn‚Äôt changed - B) Current orbital configuration predicts cooling, not warming - C) Milankovitch cycles were disproven - D) Orbital changes only affect the Southern Hemisphere
Question 2: Current atmospheric CO‚ÇÇ levels are approximately: - A) 280 ppm (same as pre-industrial) - B) 350 ppm - C) 422 ppm - D) 600 ppm
Question 3: How do scientists know that the increased CO‚ÇÇ comes from fossil fuels? - A) They can see smoke from factories - B) Carbon isotope ratios show a fossil fuel fingerprint - C) They counted all the power plants in the world - D) It‚Äôs an educated guess
Question 4: Why is the Arctic warming almost 4 times faster than the global average? - A) The Arctic is closer to the Sun - B) Ice-albedo feedback amplifies warming there - C) There are more volcanoes in the Arctic - D) The Arctic has more CO‚ÇÇ
Question 5: What caused the Younger Dryas rapid cooling event ~12,900 years ago? - A) A massive volcanic eruption - B) Decreased solar output - C) Freshwater from melting ice shutting down AMOC - D) An asteroid impact
Question 6: How long did the Younger Dryas cold period last? - A) About 100 years - B) About 1,200 years - C) About 10,000 years - D) About 100,000 years
Question 7: Which evidence rules out solar changes as the cause of current warming? - A) The Sun doesn‚Äôt affect Earth‚Äôs climate - B) Solar output has been flat/declining since 1980, and the stratosphere is cooling - C) Solar output has increased dramatically - D) Scientists haven‚Äôt studied solar output
Question 8: What percentage of climate scientists agree that humans are causing current climate change? - A) About 50% - B) About 75% - C) About 90% - D) About 99.9%
Question 9: If AMOC significantly weakens, what would likely happen to Northwestern Europe? - A) It would warm dramatically - B) It would experience significant cooling despite global warming - C) Nothing would change - D) It would experience more earthquakes
Question 10: Why is the rate of current warming important evidence for human causation? - A) Fast warming is always natural - B) Current warming is 100x faster than natural changes, ruling out natural causes - C) Warming rate doesn‚Äôt matter - D) Natural warming is always faster than human-caused warming
Question 11: What drives the sinking of water that powers AMOC? - A) Wind pushing water down - B) Cold, salty water being denser than warm, fresh water - C) The Moon‚Äôs gravitational pull - D) Underwater volcanoes
Question 12: Which statement best explains why understanding past climate change strengthens the case for human causation of current warming? - A) Past climate was always stable - B) By understanding natural causes, scientists can show they don‚Äôt explain current warming - C) Past climate changes prove current warming is natural too - D) Past climate is irrelevant to understanding current climate


25.2.2 Part B: Short Answer
Question 13: Explain why the fact that Earth was cooling for 2,000 years before recent warming is important evidence for human causation. (3-4 sentences)
Question 14: Describe the ice-albedo feedback loop and explain why it causes the Arctic to warm faster than the rest of the planet. (4-5 sentences)
Question 15: A classmate says ‚ÄúThe climate has always changed, so current warming is natural.‚Äù Using evidence from this unit, construct a response that addresses this claim. (5-6 sentences)



25.2.3 Answer Key
Multiple Choice: 1-B, 2-C, 3-B, 4-B, 5-C, 6-B, 7-B, 8-D, 9-B, 10-B, 11-B, 12-B
Short Answer Rubric:
Question 13 (4 points): - States that Milankovitch cycles predicted continued cooling (1 pt) - Explains that warming reversed this natural trend (1 pt)
- Concludes this rules out natural orbital causes (1 pt) - Uses specific timeframes or data (1 pt)
Question 14 (5 points): - Correctly defines albedo (1 pt) - Explains ice has high albedo, ocean has low albedo (1 pt) - Describes the feedback loop mechanism (1 pt) - Explains why this amplifies warming in the Arctic specifically (1 pt) - Uses specific numbers (e.g., 60% vs 6% albedo) (1 pt)
Question 15 (6 points): - Acknowledges that climate has changed naturally (1 pt) - Explains natural causes (Milankovitch cycles) and their timescales (1 pt) - States current warming is 100x faster than natural (1 pt) - Provides additional evidence (CO‚ÇÇ levels, isotopes, solar data) (1 pt) - Explains why natural factors are ruled out (1 pt) - Concludes that only human emissions explain observations (1 pt)
